title: Age-Adjusted ESR/CRP for Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: Calculates age-adjusted ESR and CRP in adult rheumatoid arthritis patients to account for age-related increases in inflammatory markers

parameters.name: sex
parameters.description: Patient sex (affects both ESR and CRP age-adjustment formulas)

parameters.name: measured_esr
parameters.description: Measured ESR value in mm/hr (optional, for comparison with age-adjusted upper limit)

parameters.name: measured_crp
parameters.description: Measured CRP value in mg/dL (optional, for comparison with age-adjusted upper limit)

result.name: age_adjusted_limits
result.description: Age-adjusted upper limits for ESR and CRP

ranges.interpretation: Age-adjusted upper limits help account for the natural increase in ESR and CRP with aging. Values above these limits may indicate active inflammation beyond what is expected for age.

references: Ranganath VK, Elashoff DA, Khanna D, et al. Age adjustment corrects for apparent differences in erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein values at the onset of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis in younger and older patients. J Rheumatol. 2005;32(6):1040-2.
Miller A, Green M, Robinson D. Simple rule for calculating normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate. BMJ. 1983;286(6361):266.
Wener MH, Daum PR, McQuillan GM. The influence of age, sex, and race on the upper reference limit of serum C-reactive protein concentration. J Rheumatol. 2000;27(10):2351-9.
Siemons L, ten Klooster PM, Vonkeman HE, et al. How age and sex affect the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein in early rheumatoid arthritis. BMC Musculoskelet Disord. 2014;15:368.
formula: ESR: Male = Age ÷ 2, Female = (Age + 10) ÷ 2; CRP: Male = Age ÷ 50, Female = (Age ÷ 50) + 0.6
notes: Age-adjusted formulas help correct for the natural increase in ESR and CRP with aging
ESR formula: Male = Age ÷ 2 mm/hr, Female = (Age + 10) ÷ 2 mm/hr
CRP formula: Male = Age ÷ 50 mg/dL, Female = (Age ÷ 50) + 0.6 mg/dL
Values above age-adjusted limits may indicate active inflammation
Particularly useful in elderly patients where conventional limits may be inappropriate
Should be used in conjunction with clinical assessment and other disease activity measures
Age-adjustment helps distinguish disease activity from age-related increases
Based on studies in healthy populations and validated in rheumatoid arthritis patients
